(Submitted by Rosalyn Roy) A rainstorm brought flooding and other complications to Channel-Port aux Basques on Saturday, as the town continues to grapple with the devastating effects of post-tropical storm Fiona. "Any time we're having weather such as what we had yesterday, it becomes very stressful for both our crews and for staff, and for the residents, because there's still a lot of unknowns," said the town's Mayor Brian Button. "Fiona is trying to keep a long legacy here, and it hasn't let up." The remnants of post-tropical storm Nicole hit much of Newfoundland on Saturday with a mixed bag of weather, with many areas across the island experiencing snow, heavy rain and ice pellets. Port aux Basques saw the highest amount of rain Saturday, said Environment Canada meteorologist Tiffany Cheeks, with about 84 millimetres of rain. Channel-Port aux Basques Mayor Brian Button says the town had to bring in additional staff to help respond to calls. (Submitted by Rosalyn Roy) The residents of Port aux Basques are no strangers to rain, but due to significant infrastructural damage caused by Fiona, Button said Saturday's rainstorm brought a series of new challenges. Button said town crews were responding to calls all day, attending to issues such as flooding basements and sewer backups. "We were having so many calls that we had to bring in additional staff," said Button. "We had to bring in some extra crews because there was just too many calls for the crews that we did have out to answer and respond to." Some residents whose homes weren't affected by Fiona experienced damage for the first time on Saturday, said Button, while other residents discovered damage they weren't previously aware of, such as a plugged up storm drain. "I know for myself yesterday, you've had people saying, 'You need to take a break,'" said Button. "But when that weekend comes and this type of weather comes, it becomes a very stressful event." Minor flooding When Port aux Basques resident Rosalyn Roy arrived home Saturday afternoon, she says she noticed flooding at Big Bridge Hill, which is just a street away from her house. Roy, who works with the independent newspaper Wreckhouse Weekly, said she got out of her car and stood in the pouring rain to take a picture of the flood. She said crews from the town quickly arrived to drain the area. "You could see the water levels going down," said Roy. "They did an awesome job of just responding quickly so it wouldn't damage homes or anything like that." Roy said many residents are used to heavy rainfall so Saturday's rainstorm didn't cause immediate concern. At this point, she said, residents look at the situation as just another thing they have to overcome. Button says crews were responding to calls all day, attending to issues such as flooding basements and sewer backups. (Submitted by Rosalyn Roy) "Normally this would be no big thing," said Roy, "but because Fiona has damaged a lot of the shoreline infrastructure this turned into a minor flooding situation. Normally, it wouldn't be the case." The rainstorm tapered off heading into Sunday, so Button says the town will continue cleanup efforts and attempt to fix damage caused by Fiona, some of which he hopes to solve before the town heads into winter. "People are on edge every time we have a weather forecast that comes in, so we're trying to work through that as well," said Button. "Fiona left us in quite the mess." New_Content: ST. JOHN'S, N.L. St. Johns resident Steve Shortall was up at 6 oclock Monday morning, Sept. 12, when something caught his eye outside his window. I looked out, and all I could see was water, he said. Shortall has lived on Waterford Bridge Road for 40 years. He said the amount of water overflowing from the Waterford River into his backyard on Monday morning was the most hes ever seen. It just looks like a pond, he said. Post-tropical storm Earl dumped 193.6 millimetres of rain on the west end of St. Johns between Saturday and Monday afternoon, flooding properties and washing out roads. Waterford Bridge Road was flooded east of Bowring Park, and it was impassable Monday morning. One commuter was trapped in his car until firefighters from the St. Johns Regional Fire Department rescued him. The Waterford River is now the Waterford Bridge Rd., River. The road is closed in the area of Corpus Christi church. Stay away from the area and watch for localized flooding. pic.twitter.com/Y6YJ5h6Hdg Keith Gosse (TelyPhotoGosse) September 12, 2022 The river was overflowing in Mount Pearl as well, so much so that firefighters were called to rescue two men from a flooded home on Forest Avenue. The walking trail next to the river from Forest Avenue to Winston Avenue was covered in water for almost a kilometre. In the east end of St. Johns, Rennies River spilled over its banks onto nearby roads, and flooded at least two properties near Portugal Cove Road. The city closed the nearby trail between Kings Bridge Road and Long Pond until Wednesday, Sept. 14. Flooding from overnight rain dropped by post-tropical storm Earl filled up a section of Portugal Cove Road Monday and covered parts of at least two properties in the area. Keith Gosse The Telegram Everything just erupted In the west end, Mooney Crescent, off Old Petty Harbour Road, was like a river, said longtime resident Bill Conway, who has lived on the street for 27 years. Conway said hes never seen a storm cause that much damage in the area. It was just torrential, torrential water coming off the hill. And then, naturally, all the gravel from underneath the pavement and all that came down, and everything just erupted, and everything just tore up. There was about 15 houses flooded, some seniors and some people who just bought houses here. It was just pure madness, he said. This is Mooney Crescent and Old Petty Harbour Road in St. Johns. Road is impassable in this area. pic.twitter.com/I8ttPyFyQ0 Keith Gosse (TelyPhotoGosse) September 12, 2022 Conway said its a close-knit neighbourhood, and everyone helps one another. He said he was out since 6 a.m. with a shovel helping to divert water from peoples homes. He said one resident had about two inches of mud in his house, with about six to eight inches of water on top of the mud. None of us expected this at all because we have storm drains down there, and theyre pretty good, they take out the water, but this rain from 4 oclock to 6 oclock was just utter madness. It was just a downpour, and the storm drains couldnt hold it, and then it tore up the roads up on the main roads, and tore them all up and beat them up, and I mean, theres no way that the road could handle all the rain that was coming through. Floodwater flows along a section of washed-out Mooney Crescent in St. Johns Monday. Keith Gosse The Telegram Its unclear how much the damage will cost the city in repairs, but Lynnann Winsor, the deputy city manager for public works, said thats something theyll look at over the next few days. At press deadline, six city roads remained closed: Symes Bridge, Powers Road, Mooney Crescent, Donovans Road, George Pond Road at Redmonds Road, and Old Petty Harbour Road between Densmores Lane and Cemetery Lane. Winsor said people should consider any trails near rivers to be impassable. City sports fields and Bowring Park also remained closed as of press deadline. A stalled car sits in the middle of a flooded section of Waterford Bridge Road in St. Johns Monday morning, Sept. 12. The driver was rescued by firefighters after his car started to fill with water. Keith Gosse The Telegram Significant flooding Flooding near St. Johns harbour also caused issues. Oceanex executive chairman Capt. Sid Hynes said in a statement that water levels in the area delayed terminal operations until 10 a.m., when the water levels dropped and it was deemed safe to begin operations again. While there was significant flooding observed in the surrounding area, the Oceanex terminal did not sustain any damage. An assessment of the auto compound is ongoing, with only a small number of autos stored in the area affected by flooding, he said. The Newfoundland dock yard is flooded, and so is the railway coastal museum. pic.twitter.com/gLVUxKMRrs Keith Gosse (TelyPhotoGosse) September 12, 2022 The Canadian Coast Guard ship Captain Molly Kool was in drydock for scheduled maintenance when flooding on the Newdock property caused the vessel to float from its blocks. In a statement, the Canadian Coast Guard said no injuries were reported, and the vessel was stable. We would like to acknowledge the crew members of the CCGS Captain Molly Kool, who took quick action to close and seal the areas of the vessel that were open for repair, to minimize the amount of water ingress, the Coast Guard said in a statement. We are working with Newdock to ensure scheduled repairs can resume quickly when site conditions improve. Workers at the Newdock shipyard in St. Johns walk through floodwater from overnight rain dropped by post-tropical Earl Monday. Keith Gosse The Telegram Dogs relocated In the Goulds neighbourhood of St. Johns, flooding in the basement of the Beagle Paws Rescue on Cochrane Pond Road forced the beagle-rescue organization to relocate its dogs. Lots of people got it a hell of a lot worse, its just difficult when youve got dogs, said manager Sandra Woito. Luckily, Woito had found foster families for six of the dogs last week, so there were only three dogs in the basement at the time of the flooding. She said their kennels are in the basement, but the dogs sleep on beds that are off the floor, so they had a way to stay out of the water. Woito said she posted online about needing someone to care for the three dogs while the shelter was cleaned up from the flooding, and many people offered to help right away. It was wonderful, Woito said. However, the flooding couldnt have happened at a more difficult time for the shelter. Woito said they had a huge influx of dogs this summer like weve never seen it before, she said, and their veterinary bills are now through the roof. The organization accepts donations year-round on its website at www.beaglepaws.com. Water erupts from a storm drain after flooding from overnight rain Monday. Keith Gosse The Telegram Climate change These sorts of weather events are expected to become more common with climate change. According to the Resilient St. Johns Community Climate Plan, which was finalized earlier this year, annual precipitation is expected to increase, and heavy precipitation events are expected to become more extreme. Climate change projections indicate that our climate is expected to become more wetter, warmer, and more extreme, the document said.

New_Content: Hey there, time traveller! This article was published 03/05/2022 (568 days ago), so information in it may no longer be current. CODY SELLAR STAFF REPORTER R.M. OF HEADINGLEY Waters pool in Sally Manns backyard and beyond. Its been nothing but headaches since the first rain storm for Headingley resident Sally Mann. Its been horrible. I didnt really think we were going to get that affected by the storm because our houses are built slightly higher, she said. But after a rainstorm piled on to a snowstorm which itself piled on to a winters worth of heavy snowfall, Manns home couldnt keep the water out. It got so the sump pump couldnt handle the amount of water coming in, and then it flooded within seconds, the resident of Dodds Road said. Mann said her basement ended up under five inches of water and mud, while outside waters submerged the street and her backyard completely. Its just nasty down there, she said. Compounding matters, Mann said her insurance company was so busy with calls from other homeowners facing the same issue that it couldnt even estimate a time an agent could make it to her house to assess the damage. Mann, who replaced her flooring not too long before the storm, said shes overwhelmed with it all. Im back to square one now. I really dont want to do it again. I just want to shut the door and walk away. But youve got to theres no other option. If we dont get it cleared out, were going to get damp and mold, Mann said. Headingley mayor John Mauseth said Dodds Road, on which he himself lives, saw the worst of the flooding, in terms of affected homes. He didnt have the exact number but said a handful of houses were flooded. Mauseth said the rural municipality was working almost 24-7 to ensure flows were open and water was flowing through as quickly as possible. Backhoes were clearing some of the larger drains and problem areas were noted for potential repairs during summer. Dodds Road in Headingley sits underwater. I cant say that Ive ever seen it quite this bad, he said. Mauseth commended local residents and public works employees who rushed out to help flooded areas with sandbagging and running pumps. Overland flooding was common in other municipalities just west of the city, as well. In the rural municipality of Rosser, public works crews worked to clear ditches and culverts and in a couple of cases, even cut a couple of roads to divert water flows. Rosser reeve Frances Smee said that entails careful examination to ensure waters are not directed toward other people or communities. Were all hands on deck dealing with this, Smee said. Brad Erb, reeve of the R.M. of MacDonald, said crews there were also clearing ditches and culverts, as well as providing sandbags to residents where localized overland flooding had occurred. Erb said he and his government were keeping an eye on provincial flood forecasts, as more rains filled the forecasts for the weekend leading into May, which came after the publication time for this paper. Christa Vann Mitchell, reeve of the R.M. of Cartier, said several areas had experienced overland flooding, with the most occurring at the Elm Creek Channel. Residences at the James Valley Hutterite Colony were affected, Vann Mitchell said, but she was not aware of any other property damage in the area. The R.M. went so far as to declare a state of local emergency due to the flooding on Apr. 24. On Apr. 27, it released a list of roads to avoid because they were under water. That announcement and others are posted at www.rm-cartier.mb.ca

New_Content: As Manitoba experiences its third straight weekend of challenging weather, some households are evacuating over rising floodwaters made worse by heavy rain and waterlogged ground. In the rural municipality of Ritchot, just south of Winnipeg, 88 households have been asked to evacuate their homes, which lie outside a ring dike. So far, only 10 households have evacuated, said Mayor Chris Ewen. Their homes are located on low-lying roads, and if the water gets too high, it may be difficult for them to leave or for emergency services to reach them, he said. "We want to make sure that when you do get that evacuation order, you've really taken into consideration your quality of life and your family members, and what that means to stay at home," Ewen said in an interview on Saturday. Joel Lemoine worked with a number of other community members to help monitor flooding just north of Ste. Agathe. (Radio-Canada) But families don't know how long they could be away from their homes if they do leave, nor does the RM's mayor. "I wish I could predict the weather and see what happens over the next few days, but it could be anywhere from a 12-hour concern all the way to a couple of weeks, depending on what the severity of the situation is," Ewen said. Just outside of Ste. Agathe, located in the RM of Ritchot, crews slept in their vehicles overnight, with each member taking turns watching the pumps and other equipment to ensure everything ran smoothly. "For the next probably week or two, we're still going to be monitoring to make sure the Red River doesn't go over capacity" and to keep an eye on the community's dike, said Joel Lemoine, who lives in the town. A tiger dam wraps around the outside of a home on Fisher River Cree Nation. The community has several other houses that are similarly protected as floodwaters rise. One household has been evacuated. (Submitted by Jeremy Neault) To the southwest of Ritchot, the city of Morden declared a local state of emergency on Saturday, as rising water levels there forced dozens of people from their homes. Further north, Fisher River Cree Nation, on the western banks of Lake Winnipeg, was also under a state of emergency. It was declared on Friday, over fears this weekend's rainfall would lead to significant risk of flooding, the First Nation said in a social media post. Crews stand guard at a dike just north of Ste. Agathe on Saturday. (Radjaa Abdelsadok/Radio-Canada) Chief David Crate says seven homes are directly affected by flooding, and one household was evacuated because road access was quickly deteriorating. "The water came up on the river about a foot since last night, and the other problem we're having, of course, is the rain now," he said. "We're getting overland flooding now." Crate says Indigenous Services Canada and the neighbouring community of Peguis First Nation provided Fisher River with inflatable Tiger Dams, which will hopefully help the flood-prone community. Winnipeggers sandbag In Winnipeg, people continue sandbagging to protect homes threatened by the rising water. Andrew Valgardson spent part of Saturday collecting sandbags provided by the City of Winnipeg at the Waverley Street garage to help protect his mother-in-law's Charleswood home. Her basement flooded from water pooling in the backyard, so he made two trips to fill his truck up with sandbags. Valgardson, who is a trucker, said the weather has also been bad for business. "With the snow and the rain and everything, roads are closed, highways are closed. Warehouses are closed. Staff can't make it to work. It's been really bad," he said. Andrew Valgardson picked up sandbags on Saturday to help protect his mother-in-law's house in Charleswood. (CBC) Bob Hunt also picked up some sandbags on Saturday. He said he hasn't had any flooding so far, but isn't taking any chances. "I err on the side of caution. If you don't have the bags, it'll flood out," he said. As rain continued to fall Saturday, he said he had "never experienced weather like this." "It's this winter from hell and it won't let go," he said. "Maybe I should invest in a boat." The rain is expected to continue throughout the weekend, eventually tapering off Sunday as the system moves from west to east. For those who need sandbags, the City of Winnipeg says they are available for free, 24 hours a day, at three locations in the city: 1220 Pacific Ave., 1090 Thomas Ave. and 1539 Waverley St.

New_Content: Several Manitoba municipalities have declared a local State of Emergency due to ongoing flooding. The R.M. of Dufferin announced on Sunday the State of Emergency was put into effect because water from the Boyne River is spilling over its banks. Its very rampant at the moment. Ive lived in this area for a long time and been along the river and never seen it this high, George Gray, the Reeve of the R.M. of Dufferin, told CTV News. Its like a wild horse coming down the river. Gray said at least half a dozen homes have been given evacuation orders just west of the Town of Carman, and more evacuations are possible. He said the western part of the municipality is the hardest hit right now, as roads have been washed out and there is a lot of overland flooding. Gray isnt expecting any more rain to hit the area but he knows that they arent out of the woods yet. There is just so much water coming from the westand it is just coming so fast, we just cant keep ahead of it. He added that the river hasnt crested yet either, noting the situation will probably get worse before it gets better. The community hall has been opened for people who have been evacuated and Gray said for those who use the hall, they must register first so the R.M. knows how many people it has. The Town of Winnipeg Beach also announced a local State of Emergency to deal with the flooding situation in the area. A statement from the towns mayor said the decision was made so council can bring in the equipment and contractors needed to assist with infrastructure that may be in jeopardy. Mayor Tony Pimentel called the move a proactive measure. At this time our public works and utility staff are working closely with our emergency measures officer in order to ensure we are protected, Pimentel said in a statement. Pimentel is reminding residents to stay away from areas where water is flowing. He said there are no concerns for evacuations and if things change, an update will be provided. Joining the R.M. of Dufferin and Winnipeg Beach is the Town of Arborg, the R.M. of Gimli and the Long Plain First Nation. All places announced local States of Emergency Sunday due to ongoing flooding issues. Arborg said in a Facebook post that the emergency would be in effect until May 21, noting the town is dealing with flooding that needs prompt action. Potential evacuees are in the process of being notified and arrangements are being made for accommodations, the post said. Residents are being reminded to not travel through water that is over roads. Long Plain First Nation said Elders, people with medical needs and those who have impassible lanes are being evacuated and this will continue to happen until the emergency is over. The R.M. of Gimli said in a Facebook post the measures being taken are proactive to protect infrastructure and properties. No evacuations have been required at this time.
